questions.text: Which of the following statements about medicolegal autopsy is wrong?

choices.text: Requisition from police or magistrate is required
Objective reporting to the police or magistrate is required

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Consent of kin is required

 

Explanation:

Consent of kin is not required for medicolegal autopsy but is required for pathological autopsy.

 

Medicolegal autopsy/necropsy/postmortem examination - specialized scientific examination of a deceased body conducted primarily for legal purposes.

A complete autopsy is a detailed examination of the entire body, both internally and externally, including the brain, chest and abdominal organs, and musculoskeletal systems.

 

Objectives
  • Identification and determination of cause and time of death
  • For newborn infants, determine whether the child was born alive and viable
  • For mutilated, fragmented, or skeletal remains, determine if they are human, the probable cause of death, and the time since death
  • Restore the body to the best possible cosmetic condition before releasing it to relatives

Essential Requirements
  • Performed by a registered medical practitioner with specialized training or experience in forensic medicine (forensic pathology)
  • Meticulous examination
  • Complete autopsy (Option A ruled out)
  • Materials sent to forensic science laboratory Preservation of records and evidence
  • Objective reporting to the police or magistrate is required. (Option D ruled out)
  • Consent of kin is not required (Option B)
  • Requisition from police or magistrate (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding clinical autopsy is false?

choices.text: Tests are done in a medical laboratory

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Always complete

 

Explanation:

Clinical autopsy can be partial or complete

 

Clinical/Pathological Autopsy:

  • Conducted to determine the cause of death
  • Requires consent from the next of kin or relatives (Option A ruled out)
  • Requested by a clinician (Option B ruled out)
  • The autopsy report is provided to the clinician
  • Necessary tests are done in the concerned medical laboratory (Option D ruled out)
  • Complete or partial autopsy, depending on the consent given (Option C)

questions.text:
Given below are a few statements on various kinds of autopsy. Which of them is true?


	A psychological autopsy is done after suicide.
	Virtopsy combines 2D surface scanning/CAD photogrammetry with radiologic imaging like MRI.
	Psychological autopsy involves data collection.
	The ability to identify the infection status of antemortem from postmortem wounds is limited in Virtopsy.
	Easy to identify postmortem artifacts using Virtopsy
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All except 2 and 5

 

Explanation:

 

Virtual autopsy/Virtopsy

Virtopsy is a non-invasive alternative to traditional autopsy using imaging instead of physical dissection.

Technology
  • Utilizes 3D surface scanning, MSCT, MRI, and CAD photogrammetry to create a digital, objective record. (Option D)
  • This can be shared online for secondary opinions and presented as evidence in court if required.

Features
  • Provides high-resolution, colored 3D images in various sections
  • Allows visualization of body surfaces, deeper tissues, organs, coronary vessels, pulmonary emboli, soft tissue trauma, and bone injuries

Limitations
  • High cost of equipment
  • Radiologic imaging limitations, interference from metal
  • Limited ability to distinguish internal organ colors
  • Incomplete database for diagnosis
  • Challenges in identifying infection status, antemortem vs. postmortem wounds (Options B and C ruled out)
  • Difficulty in identifying postmortem artifacts and subtle tissue injuries, and differentiating certain pathological conditions (Option D)

 

Psychological autopsy - Meticulous collection of data after someone’s suicide to understand the circumstances of their death.

questions.text: 2-5% of autopsies cannot determine the cause of death even after extensive lab investigations. What are such autopsies called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Negative autopsy

 

Explanation:

In a negative autopsy, the cause of death remains unknown

 

Obscure autopsy (Option A ruled out)

Negative autopsy (Option B)
  • The cause of death may not be clear at the time of dissection but can often be determined after detailed clinical, and laboratory investigations, and interviews
  • Examples: Epilepsy, reflex vagal inhibition, uremia, and anesthetic overdose
  • The cause of death remains unknown even after extensive laboratory investigations
  • Occurs in 2-5% of all postmortem cases

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient was found deceased under unknown circumstances, and a detailed autopsy was requested to investigate possible causes of death. During the procedure, the police surgeon decided to use an evisceration technique that involves dissecting and examining each organ system individually rather than removing the organs as a whole. Which of the following techniques is he most likely using?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Gohn

 

Explanation:

 

Evisceration techniques in autopsy:

En Masse (Letulle)

(Option A ruled out)
  • Removing most internal organs in one full swoop
  • Rapid technique
  • Dissection afterward is lengthy
  • Leaves all attachments intact

Virchow’s Method

(Option D ruled out)
  • Organs are removed individually
  • Useful if the pathological focus is on a single organ

In Situ Dissection (Rokitansky)

(Option B ruled out)
  • Organs are dissected within the body with minimal evisceration
  • Rarely performed, but useful in cases involving highly transmissible diseases

En block (Ghon)

(Option C)
  • Separate block dissection and organ separation
  • Relatively quick
  • Preserves most important inter-organ relationships

questions.text: A forensic pathologist is conducting an autopsy on a middle-aged female. The case requires a thorough examination of the thoracic and abdominal organs while maintaining an aesthetic appearance for potential display. Which incision technique is most appropriate to ensure optimal exposure of internal organs and accommodate forensic display requirements?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Y-shaped incision

Explanation

The most appropriate incision technique is the Y-shaped Incision, also known as the Rokitansky or Mercedes incision.

  • This technique is preferred for its combination of excellent exposure and aesthetic preservation.
  • The incision starts from the shoulders, meeting at the sternum, and then continues as a single midline incision to the pubic symphysis
  • This method leaves the neck and chest region largely intact, which is critical for cases requiring public display or when the identity of the deceased is not yet confirmed.
  • It provides a wide flap of skin that can be retracted to expose the thoracic and abdominal organs.

I-shaped Incision (Standard Midline) (Option A): This is the most common technique for a rapid autopsy. It involves a single vertical incision from the suprasternal notch to the pubic symphysis. While it provides good access, it is not ideal for aesthetic purposes or forensic display as it bisects the torso.

Modified Y-shaped Incision (Optiopn C): A variation of the Y-incision, the modified Y-incision typically involves a single midline incision from the suprasternal notch to symphysis pubis. The incision extends from suprasternal notch over the clavicle to its centre on both sides and then passes upwards over the neck behind the ear.

T-shaped Incision: This incision involves a vertical midline cut from the sternal notch to the umbilicus, with a horizontal cut across the chest. It offers good access but is less aesthetically pleasing than the Y-shaped incision due to the prominent horizontal cut.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male is found dead in his apartment under suspicious circumstances. Upon initial external examination, petechial hemorrhages are noted around the eyes. The scene suggests a possible asphyxial death, as there are no overt signs of trauma. During the autopsy by the police surgeon, which among the following has to be opened first to identify definitive signs of asphyxia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cranial cavity

 

Explanation:

  • In cases of suspected asphyxial death, the cranial cavity is typically opened first.
  • The order of opening is the cranium, Thorax (Option A), abdomen, and neck. (To get a clear field of study for neck structures after draining of blood from neck vessels via the head and trunk)
  • Asphyxial deaths frequently involve abnormalities in the lungs and airway, such as congestion, petechiae, froth in the airways, or other indicators of respiratory failure.
  • This helps confirm if the cause of death is indeed related to impaired oxygen exchange or suffocation.
  • Examining the heart may also reveal signs of right-sided heart failure due to hypoxia.
  • Abdomen is first to be opened in stillbirth


 

Order of Opening Cavities

Head Injury Cases, Asphyxial Deaths

The skull opened before the thorax and abdomen.

Pneumothorax, Venous air embolism

The Thorax opened first, then the skull.

 

Abdominal cavity (Option B): While the abdominal cavity could be opened to assess for trauma or distension, these findings are less likely to provide direct clues in cases of asphyxia unless abdominal trauma is suspected, which is not indicated here. Thus, it is typically examined after the thoracic cavity.

Pelvic cavity (Option D): Trauma to the pelvic organs or fractures is more relevant in cases involving physical injury or sexual assault. These findings are not directly associated with asphyxial deaths, so this cavity is not examined first.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is found dead at home and poisoning is suspected. During the autopsy, the forensic pathologist decides to dissect the stomach to examine its contents. Which of the following is the most appropriate procedure for stomach dissection to preserve evidence of poisoning and ensure accurate forensic analysis?

choices.text: Open the stomach along the greater curvature and discard the contents
Open the stomach along the lesser curvature and collect the contents for toxicology
Open the stomach along the greater curvature and collect the contents for toxicology
Incise the stomach along the pylorus and drain the contents into the small intestine

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Open the stomach along the greater curvature and collect the contents for toxicology

 

Explanation:

  • In forensic autopsies, the stomach is usually opened along the greater curvature to minimize disruption of stomach anatomy and allows the pathologist to collect and examine the stomach contents effectively, which is critical in cases of suspected poisoning.

 

Procedure for Stomach Dissection:

  1. Two ligatures are applied at the cardiac end of the esophagus and two ligatures are below the pyloric end of the stomach.
  2. The stomach is removed by cutting between the double ligatures at both ends.
  3. The stomach is then opened along the greater curvature.
  4. The mucous membrane is examined for the presence of any stains, congestion, hemorrhage, desquamation, ulceration, sloughing, or perforation.
  5. The contents of the stomach are noted with respect to quantity, nature of material/food, state of digestion, color, and smell.

 

Open the stomach along the greater curvature and discard the contents (Option A): This is incorrect. While opening along the greater curvature is common for ease of access, discarding the contents is completely inappropriate when poisoning is suspected. The stomach contents are crucial evidence for toxicological analysis.

Open the stomach along the lesser curvature and collect the contents for toxicology (Option B): This is generally considered less ideal than opening along the greater curvature. Opening along the lesser curvature can make it more difficult to fully visualize and collect all the contents due to the anatomical folds and the proximity of blood vessels and nerves. However, collecting the contents is the correct step for toxicology.

Incise the stomach along the pylorus and drain the contents into the small intestine (Option D): This is incorrect and would contaminate other parts of the digestive tract. Draining the contents into the small intestine would mix the gastric contents with intestinal contents, making toxicological analysis much more complicated and potentially diluting or altering the evidence. It would also lead to loss of the isolated gastric contents as evidence.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man was found dead under suspicious circumstances, and his body was buried without a post-mortem examination. Months later, new evidence suggests foul play, and the family now requests further investigation. The local police inspector wishes to exhume the body to re-examine the cause of death. Which of the following authorities is legally empowered to order an exhumation in this case?

 

A) Police Inspector
B) First Class Magistrate
C) Sub-Inspector of Police
D) Medical Officer
E) Sub-Divisional Magistrate
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Only B and E

 

Explanation:

In India, only specific magistrates can order exhumation:

  • First Class, District, Sub-Divisional, Executive Magistrates.
  • Law enforcement cannot order exhumation independently.

 

Exhumation
  • Legal disinterment of a previously buried body.
  • Conducted when post-burial examination is necessary.

Common Reasons
  • Criminal Cases:
    • Re-examine suspected homicides disguised as suicides/accidents.
    • Investigate deaths from criminal abortion or negligence.
    • Retrieve evidence (e.g., bullets).
  • Civil Cases:
    • Insurance/worker's compensation claims.
    • Professional negligence cases.
    • Inheritance disputes or identity verification.
    • Correct burial errors (If the wrong body was buried)

Procedure Requirements
  • Timing & Personnel:
    • Must be conducted during daylight (start in the morning).
    • A medical officer, magistrate, and police officer are required.
  • Documentation:
    • Verify grave location and markers.
    • Collect soil samples (above, below, and beside the body/coffin).
    • Document body position and appearance.
    • Create a detailed grave diagram.
    • Photograph grave, coffin, and body.

Handling Guidelines
  • Avoid altering the body (no use of disinfectants or pesticides).
  • Use plank or plastic sheet for removal if decomposition is minimal.
  • Transport the body to the mortuary for post-mortem examination.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man who had been incarcerated for political dissent is reported to have died under suspicious circumstances. The autopsy reveals multiple injuries consistent with physical torture. In considering international guidelines for the medical investigation of such cases, which key document outlines principles and standards for identifying and investigating torture for a Police Surgeon?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Istanbul Protocol

 

Explanation:

Istanbul Protocol

  • Official name: UN Manual on the Effective Investigation and Documentation of Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman, or Degrading Treatment or Punishment

  • Key international guideline for the medical and legal investigation of torture

  • Provides detailed procedures for documenting:

    • Physical evidence of torture

    • Psychological consequences of torture

  • Widely used by:

    • Forensic experts

    • Human rights investigators

    • Police surgeons

  • Essential in cases of custodial death, political torture, and ill-treatment

  • Not to be confused with the Declaration of Istanbul, which deals with organ trafficking

Declaration of Istanbul (Clarification)

  • Focus: Organ trafficking and transplant tourism

  • Provides ethical guidance on:

    • Organ donation

    • Prevention of illegal organ trade

  • Not related to torture documentation or custodial deaths

Comparison of International Declarations

Declaration / Document

Focus / Purpose

Istanbul Protocol

Documentation and investigation of torture and ill-treatment

Declaration of Tokyo

Guidelines for doctors on torture related to detention and imprisonment (Option A ruled out)

Declaration of Helsinki

Ethical principles for medical research involving human subjects (Option C ruled out)

Nuremberg Code

Ethics in human experimentation post-WWII (Option D ruled out)

Geneva Conventions

Treatment of combatants and civilians during armed conflict

Declaration of Malta

Guidelines on physicians’ roles during hunger strikes, especially in custodial settings

Explanation:

  • The given image depicts El Planton

 

Torture:

  • Defined as deliberate, systemic, or wanton infliction of physical or mental suffering by one or more persons acting alone or on the orders of any authority to force another person to yield information or for any other reason.

 

Physical torture subtypes

Types of Torture

Description

El Plantón

(Option D)
  • Victim is forced to stand for extended periods in the ‘Army Corps’ poster or body folding or on one leg.
  • Dependent edema and petechiae.

Scaphism

(Option A)
  • An ancient form of execution involving being trapped between two boats and subjected to insects and exposure.


 

Dry Submarine

(Option B)
  • Form of suffocation where the victim's head is wrapped in a plastic bag, causing breathing difficulty.
  • Lung petechiae are seen.


 

Picana/Electric cattle prod

(Option C)
  • An electric torture method that applies electric shocks to the genital region.
  • Reddish brown lesions at points of contact with burning and scarring.

Torture: Defined as deliberate, systemic or wanton infliction of physical or mental suffering by one or more persons acting alone or on the orders of any authority to force another person to yield information or for any other reason.

Types of torture

Description

Belana or The roller

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Telefono

 

Explanation:

The given image depicts Telefono

 

Torture: Defined as deliberate, systemic or wanton infliction of physical or mental suffering by one or more persons acting alone or on the orders of any authority to force another person to yield information or for any other reason.

 

Physical torture subtypes

Types of torture

Description

Telefono/Ear torture

(Option A)
  • Repeated and simultaneous slapping of both the ears by open hands of the torturer.
  • Ruptured tympanic membrane.



 

Falanga or Bastinado

(Option B)
  • Most common form of torture.
  • Victim is suspended upside down and then beaten on the soles by blunt instruments such as sticks, clubs or rifle butts.
  • Haematoma of the soles.

Passing the board or Beating buttocks

(Option C)
  • Victim is forced to the ground and beaten viciously with the board club or baton on the buttock.

Nail torture

(Option D)
  • Victims' nails (either fingernails or toenails) are subjected to various forms of abuse, such as being pulled out, crushed, or having sharp objects driven under them.

Torture: Defined as deliberate, systemic or wanton infliction of physical or mental suffering by one or more persons acting alone or on the orders of any authority to force another person to yield information or for any other reason.

Types of torture

Description

(Option D)
